in such a way that one amount gets bigger as another gets smaller: Sometimes it seems that press coverage of an event is inversely proportional to its true importance (= the more important the event, the less attention is paid to it). One study found that the risk of a stroke is inversely related to eating nuts. See
inverse
inverse proportion
More examplesFewer examplesThese public contributions would vary inversely with income.Prices are inversely related to crop size: for every 1 percent increase in crop size, the industry can expect a 1 percent decrease in price.Inversely, the cloud cover helped to keep overnight temperatures up.
